overview: What criteria you must meet, how to apply and information about the Life in the UK Test to become a British citizen
title: Becoming a British citizen

table.body:
You can apply for British citizenship if:

- you’re 18 or over
- you’re of sound mind - eg you can make your own decisions (or have someone applying on your behalf who can)
- you’re of good character
- you will continue to live in the UK or work for a part of the British government, an international organisation or a company established in the UK
- you’re able to communicate in English, Welsh or Scottish Gaelic 
- you've passed the Life in the UK test

You must also have:

- lived in the UK for at least 5 years before the date of your application (unless your spouse is a British citizen)
- spent no more than 450 days outside the UK during those 5 years
- spent no more than 90 days outside the UK in the last 12 months 
- not broken any immigration rules

##Fees
There are several fees for each stage of citizenship:

$D
[Download 'Fees for British citizenship applications' (PDF, 1.2MB)](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/sitecontent/documents/britishcitizenship/nationality-fees.pdf "Fees for British citizenship applications, PDF, 1.2MB"){:rel="external"}
$D
table.title: Check if you can apply

table.body:
If you are married to, or the civil partner of, a British citizen, you can apply for citizenship if:

- you’re 18 or over
- you’re of sound mind - eg you can make your own decisions (or have someone applying on your behalf who can)
- you’re able to communicate in English, Welsh or Scottish Gaelic 
- you've passed the Life in the UK test
- you’re of good character

Unless your spouse or civil partner works abroad for a part of the British government, an international organisation or a company established in the UK, you must also have:

- lived in the UK for at least 3 years
- spent no more than 270 days outside the UK in those 3 years
- spent no more than 90 days outside the UK in the last 12 months
- not broken any immigration rules
table.title: If your spouse is a British citizen

table.body:
You have to take the Life in the UK Test as part of your application. The test includes questions about British traditions and customs, as well as proving that you can speak English.

You can [book your Life in the UK Test and buy the official handbook](/book-life-in-uk-test "book your Life in the UK Test and buy the official handbook").
table.title: Life in the UK Test

table.body:
There are 3 ways to apply for British citizenship:

- an individual application
- using the Nationality Checking Service (NCS)
- through an agent or representative

##Make an individual application
To make an individual application you must fill in the following form:

$D
[Download form AN - application for naturalisation as a British citizen (PDF, 111KB)](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/sitecontent/applicationforms/nationality/form_an.pdf "Application for naturalisation as a British citizen"){:rel="external"}
$D

You must also read the guidance booklet which tells you how to fill in the form and what other documents you need to provide:

$D
[Download guide AN - naturalisation as a British citizen (PDF, 202KB)](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/sitecontent/applicationforms/nationality/guide_an.pdf "Guide to naturalisation as a British citizen"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Apply using the NCS

The NCS is run by local councils and they can help you make your application. [Check if your local council has an NCS.](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/britishcitizenship/applying/checkingservice/checkingservicelocations/ "Check if your local council has an Nationality Checking Service"){:rel="external"}

##Apply through an agent or representative

An agent or representative is a private company or individual that can help you with your application and give you advice. 

You should check if an agent or representative is registered with the [Office of the Immigration Service Commissioner.](http://www.oisc.gov.uk/ "Office of the Immigration Service Commissioner"){:rel="external"}

*[NCS]: Nationality Checking Service

##Fees
There are several fees for each stage of citizenship:

$D
[Download 'Fees for British citizenship applications' (PDF, 1.2MB)](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/sitecontent/documents/britishcitizenship/nationality-fees.pdf "Fees for British citizenship applications, PDF, 1.2MB"){:rel="external"}
$D
table.title: How to apply

table.body:
If you are in the UK, you should send your application form, fee and any supporting documents to:

$A
UK Border Agency
Department 1
PO Box 306
LIVERPOOL
L2 0QN
$A

If you are in the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man, you should send your application, fee and documents to the Lieutenant-Governor.

If you are in a British overseas territory, you should send them to the Governor of that territory.

If you are elsewhere, you should send them to the nearest [British Consulate, Embassy or High Commission.](http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/find-an-embassy/ "Find an embassy"){:rel="external"}

##Fees
There are several fees for each stage of citizenship:

$D
[Download 'Fees for British citizenship applications' (PDF, 1.2MB)](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/sitecontent/documents/britishcitizenship/nationality-fees.pdf "Fees for British citizenship applications, PDF, 1.2MB"){:rel="external"}
$D
table.title: Where to send your application

table.body:
You will get a letter confirming your application. It can take up to 4 weeks for you to get the confirmation.

A decision about your application will usually be made within 6 months, but some applications can take longer.

You will be told if you need to give more information to help with your application. You should also contact the UK Border Agency if your situation changes (eg, you move house, get married or are arrested) during your application.

$C
**Nationality contact centre**  
0845 010 5200 
<ukbanationalityenquiries@ukba.gsi.gov.uk> 
$C

You might be asked to attend an interview where you will need to speak without an interpreter.
table.title: After you’ve applied

table.body:
If your application is successful, you will be invited to attend a citizenship ceremony. 

%You must attend a citizenship ceremony if you're living in the UK at the time. %

Your ceremony will usually take place close to where you live. 

You are usually allowed to take 2 guests with you and you must take your invitation with you when you go to your ceremony.

Citizenship ceremonies are organised by your local council and are usually done in groups. If you want to arrange a private ceremony or have any special requirements, you can [organise your citizenship ceremony with your council](/organise-citizenship-ceremony-council "Organise your citizenship ceremony").

##During the ceremony

You will have to make an 'oath of allegiance' (or you can make an 'affirmation' if you prefer not to swear by God) and a pledge. This means you will promise to respect the rights, freedoms and laws of the UK.

##Citizenship certificate

You will be presented with your certificate of British citizenship and a welcome pack. 

Some local councils arrange for photographs or videos of the event to be available for you to buy.
table.title: Citizenship ceremonies
